metadata.title: Fracture, Sacral Stress
anatomical location body part affected: Any aspect of the sacrum, sacral body, sacral crests, sacral hiatus, superior articular process, transverse processes, or promontory of the sacrum

Sacral fractures are defined by the zone in which they occur(13) –Zone I fractures occur in the sacral ala laterally to the sacral foramina –Zone II fractures occur in the sacral foramina –Zone III are central fractures, involving the sacral canal

ICD-10 codes.S32.1: fracture of sacrum (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Sacral stress fracture (SSF) may manifest suddenly or insidiously. Symptoms include intractable pain in the lower back and/or pelvis.(1) The pain may extend into the buttocks and groin(2,3)
Patients may report dull pain in the low back or sacrum. Patients may or may not have radicular symptoms(13)
There may be tenderness to palpation over the sacrum. In cases with pelvic ring involvement, tenderness into the groin may also be present(13)

The patient may complain of increased pain with weight-bearing  activities and present with an antalgic gait. Pain generally eases with rest.(4) However, as the condition progresses, pain will be experienced during normal daily activities and even at rest(10) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: SSF occurs mainly in two different patient populations–Women with a history of osteoporosis (insidious onset or mild trauma)(5)-Can result from low-energy  falls such as from standing or sitting.(13)Many older adultpatients with osteoporosis may not be able to recall a specific injury or incidence–Young female athletes-SSF in young athletes may be related to the female athlete triad(4)-Disordered eating-Amenorrhea-Osteoporosis-SSF may also occur as a result of participation in repetitive sport activities such as long-distance  running(2) or excessivephysical training(4)

Stress fractures are said to be caused by insufficiency or fatigue(6)–Insufficiency fractures occur when normal stresses are placed on bone with decreased mineralization and elasticresistance(14)–Fatigue fractures occur when abnormal forces are applied to normal bone, such as in long-distance  running(14)
pathogenesis: Bones can develop microfractures when bone resorption exceeds bone formation. With prolonged imbalance,microfractures can progress to stress fractures(10)

Types of stress fractures(6)–Insufficiency fractures-A deteriorating skeletal system (due to osteoporosis) is placed under forces it cannot sustain and a stress fracture results–Fatigue fractures-A healthy skeletal system is placed under atypical forces it cannot sustain and a stress fracture results
risk factors: Female athlete triad (disordered eating, amenorrhea, and osteoporosis)(4)

overall contraindications precautions: If there is a history of osteoporosis, use precautions during the examination and while performing manual therapy to avoid causing additional fractures. Also avoid excessive spinal flexion and extension to minimize risk of additional fractures
Athletes will often be ordered to avoid bearing weight on the pelvis until they can walk pain free, usually 1–2 weeks.(8) The clinician must confirm weight-bearing  status with the treating physician
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: What are the present symptoms? When did the symptoms begin? Any recent trauma? Inquire about typical footwear

course of treatment.medical management: Treatment typically is conservative.The physician may restrict the patient’s weight-bearing Sacroplasty for treatment of painful sacral insufficiency stress fractures is a treatment option that involves percutaneous injection of polymethylmethacrylate(11) Researchers in the United States found sacroplasty to be a safe and effective treatment for patients not responding to conservative treatment in a retrospective review involving 57 patients between 2004 and 2011(11)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Commonly, NSAIDs and vitamin D and calcium supplements will be recommended.(6) Opioids may be prescribed for painful sacral insufficiency fractures
diagnostic tests completed: X-rays  of sacrum may be misleading and reportedly are inadequate for this diagnosis; however, they may be used to rule out other pathology(4)
The following tests may be used to assist in making the diagnosis(15)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Weight-bearing  activities typically aggravate symptoms. Pain generally eases with rest(4)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Symptoms include intractable pain in the lower back and/or pelvis.(1) The pain may extend into the buttocks and groin.(2,3) Note any tenderness to palpation over the sacrum
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). SSF may be the cause of low back pain in older adult females with osteoporosis. Patient may have intractable pain and tenderness to palpation
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could indicate an exacerbation of the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: In older adult patients, the clinician should note any supplemental oxygen, etc. Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Existing pelvic fractures increase the risk of SSF(1)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, osteoporosis, osteopenia, osteoporosisrelated  fractures, Paget’s disease, liver transplantation, female athlete triad,(6) and/or prolonged corticosteroid use
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs). Radiation therapy increases the risk of SSF(7)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing. In the young athlete, is there an eating disorder or amenorrhea?

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in sports? If so, what is the patient’s training schedule and level of competition? SSF may occur as a result of participation in repetitive sport activities such as long-distance running(2) or excessive physical training
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document prior functional limitations, required assistance with ADLs, and any adaptive equipment the patient has at home
social and occupational history.living environment: Number of stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Evaluate for assistive gait devices(8) -What is the weight-bearing  status and can the patient comply with it? –Evaluate for the use of pelvic corsets and sacroiliac joint belts for support(6)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate balance reactions in stance as weight-bearing  status permits
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally and compare Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity –Approximately 2% of stress fractures caused by insufficiency will disrupt lumbosacral nerve roots(6)Assess mobility level
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Frequently the patient presents with a decreased cadence and noticeably painful gait(6) –Biomechanical evaluation of gait -Heel strike -Toe off -Hip hiking or circumduction -Trendelenburg gait pattern
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle testing of lower extremity musculature as pain allows
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Assess for lumbosacral lordosis –Assess foot alignment –Assess hips for symmetry -Posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) -Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) -Iliac crest
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Often limited low thoracic/lumber ROM will be observed(6) –Goniometric measurements of hip motions should be noted
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Reflex testing –Assess quadriceps reflex –Assess Achilles reflex –Assess hamstring reflex Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –Patient self-assessment  questionnaires -Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) -Back Index -Oswestry Disability Index(ODI)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Complete a lower extremity dermatome scan
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisto aid in the diagnosis, having a patient perform single-leg  hopping may elicit symptoms at the stress fracture site(10) –Single leg sit to stand. Pain or instability suggests sacroiliac joint involvement
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess as indicated in the older adult population

cryotherapy contraindications: Cryotherapy  contraindications -Raynaud’s syndrome -Cryoglobulinemia -Cold urticaria -Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria -Impaired circulation -Over area of nerve regrowth
cryotherapy precautions: Cryotherapy  precautions -Hypertension -Hypersensitivity to cold -Over an acute wound -Over superficial nerves

Aquatic therapy  contraindications/precautions -Fear of water -Avoid warm/hot water if patient is pregnant or has multiple sclerosis, increased risk of hemorrhage (e.g., on anticoagulant medications), impaired thermal regulation, acute inflammation, fever, edema, thrombophlebitis, or acute rheumatoid arthritis -Epilepsy -Cardiovascular or pulmonary disease -Open wounds, catheters, colostomies, IVs, G-tubes -Urinary or fecal incontinence -Certain dermatologic conditions (e.g., ichthyosis, infection) -Venous ulcers -Tissues damaged by radiation therapy -Peripheral vascular disease -Respiratory impairment -More than half-body  immersion during pregnancy

Thermotherapy  contraindications -Decreased circulation -Decreased sensation -Acute/subacute traumatic and inflammatory conditions -Skin infections -Impaired cognition or language barrier -Malignancy -Liniments -Presence of or tendency for hemorrhage or edema -Heat rubs
contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
electrotherapy contraindications precaut: Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions -Do not place electrodes near: -carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads -Osteomyelitis -Hemorrhage -Impaired sensation, mental status, communication -Cardiovascular disease  -Malignancy -Dermatological conditions -Proximity of electromagnetic radiation -In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen -In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck -History of spontaneous abortion in pregnant women
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Pain (limiting strength and ROM) and impaired function
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Malignancy(1) Osteomyelitis(1) Lumbar radiculitis Sacroiliac joint dysfunction/hyper-  or hypomobility Spinal stenosis(1) Vertebral fracture Trochanteric bursitis(1) Benign tumor(4)
prognosis: The prognosis is excellent with conservative treatment; improvement is noted 1–2weeks after fracture, and symptoms typically resolve completely after 6–12 months(6)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthopedic surgeon for possible sacroplasty to inject surgical cement into the sacrum and treat the stress fracture(3) Medical, nutritional, and psychological intervention for female athlete triad Orthotist for the fabrication of custom orthotics
treatment summary: Insufficiency fractures(6) –The patient may participate in judicious weight-bearing  exercise; pain is to be used as a guide to tolerance of the activity –Immediate mobilization is recommended in most patients –Assistive devices should be implemented as indicated

Fatigue fractures(6) –Activity modification – decrease forceful physical training –An initial stage of relative rest . restore functional ability and return to: Ability to return to sport and sport training

maintenance or prevention: Vitamin D and calcium supplementation for osteoporosis as directed by physician
